DOC.HEAD: Reduced Ties with Romania Planned Following Crackdown, Officials Say
Eds: INSERTS 4th graf: ``A massacre,'' to give massacre quote
With AM-Romania Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is preparing to reduce U.S. ties with Romania following that country's ``brutal and violent'' crackdown on anti-government demonstrations, U.S. officials said Thursday. The officials said the cutbacks could affect programs of economic, scientific and commercial cooperation with Romania and that an announcement could come as early as Friday. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher hinted at the possibility of sanctions, saying the administration was ``carefully reviewing'' possible steps against Romania. ``A massacre of undetermined proportions is believed to have taken place'' in Romania over the past several days, Boucher said. He said the U.S. Embassy in Bucharest reported that 13 young people were killed Thursday by automatic weapons fire from government security forces during a major demonstration. Other fatalities may have occurred as well, he said. ``Anti-regime demonstrations in Timisoara and the government's brutal and violent crackdown against them continue,'' said Boucher, who noted that some reports put the death toll since the upheaval began at several thousand. It was not clear whether the United States, as part of a sanctions program, is planning to reverse a 1988 decision to send to Romania weapons grade uranium. The 16.4 kilograms of uranium are slated to be used at the Triga reactor near Bucharest, a facility for teaching, basic research and the production of radioactive isotopes. Such isotopes are commonly used in medical tests. But opponents said the amount of uranium is large enough to make a bomb. U.S. trade with Romania has declined sharply since 1988 when that country was deprived of the right to sell its exports at the lowest possible tariff rates under the so-called Most Favored Nation system. Boucher said President Nicolae Ceaucescu has blamed the unrest on ``fascists and imperialist circles abroad. ``In fact, however, the growing anti-government movement encompasses all of Romania's nationalities, who are showing their unalterable opposition to Ceausescu and his policies,'' he said. Boucher said the U.S. ambassador in Romania, Alan Green, has been rebuffed in repeated efforts to deliver a strong protest against the crackdown in Timisoara. Deputy Secretary Lawrence Eagleburger attempted to see the Romanian ambassador in Washington on Wednesday but was told the ambassador was unavailable. ``We have summoned the Romanian ambassador to come to the Department tomorrow to receive our protest,'' Boucher said. Telephone calls to the Romanian Embassy on Thursday were not answered. Protests against the repression in Romania have been made in statements issued by NATO, the European Community and by the 35-nation Helsinki group. Members of the Warsaw Pact, of which Romania is a participant, have criticized the Romanian actions individually, Boucher said, adding that the Bush administration has asked the Soviet Union to use whatever influence it has on Romania. He did not characterize the Soviet response.
